context:
** Before the "Mighty Mo" was stolen by Hawaii to be put on display, it was home ported for many years in Bremerton, Washington at the naval shipyard. In Bremerton, I visited her on four occasions always bringing new guests to witness this great naval vessel where the signing of the WWII peace declaration was held.
  A grand piece of American History, my fellow Washingtonians were grieved at the political decision to tow her to Hawaii thus making it difficult for most Americans to visit her. Now, she can only be seen by those making the trip to Hawaii and thus most Americans will never get the chance to pay their respects to this great piece of American history. Truly a shame that politics was the only reason she was stolen away...

replies.context: Stolen?  It's in PH as a symbol of the end of the war in the pacific, right there near the USS Arizona, the beginning of the pacific war.  Are there any other war items you and other Washingtonians would like to claim as their own?  Just how many more visits do you deserve?
Was she "stolen" or "transferred"? I'm pretty sure the Skipper has to go where the DoD tells him/her to go -personal feelings aside..

The USS Missouri is currently on display at Pearl Harbor, in Oahu, Hawaii.  Did you know that Hawaii is part of the USA?  Anyone can get on an aircraft, and fly to Hawaii, as I have done.  I spent an entire day at Pearl Harbor, but I didn't see everything, so I need to go back.  Also, don't miss the US Army Coast Artillery Museum, at Waikiki Beach.
I also did a main deck tour of USS Missouri, about 1988, when she was back in service.  That was in San Francisco harbor.
USS Missouri was part of the Iowa Class of USN battleships, and was first commissioned in  1944.  She also served during the Korean War against communist "North" Korea, and Communist China, and during the Gulf War of 1991.
The first shots of the Gulf War were fired from the “Mighty Mo,” as cruise missiles were launched from her.
Hawaii gave us O'Bama. According to the fake birth certificate. Do I look impressed? No.
In one powerful visit you can see the start of WW2 and the end of WW2.  I couldn’t think of a more appropriate way to honor the sacrifices of the greatest generation.

The state of Washington had their chance to keep a truly iconic battleship of WWII.  The USS Washington was the only US battleship in WWII to square of with another nations battleship when she annihilated the Japanese battleship Kirishima at Guadalcanal.
The ship was offered to the state, but they didn't want her, so she was scrapped instead.  You can visit her sister ship, the USS North Carolina, in Wilmington, NC.

I worked at Bremerton for many years and had the privilege of standing watches on the Missouri while it was there (impressive ship, inside and out!). I watched when it was towed from Bremerton for the last time and by lucky coincidence I was in Hawaii when it arrived there. They towed it parallel to Waikiki on a long cable so it looked like it was under power, the sight made chills run down my spine. I was at Pearl Harbor the next day, adjacent to the channel entrance when it was towed in, it was an awe inspiring sight. I was sorry to see her leave Bremerton but she is definitely where she belongs, a permanent symbol in the place where the war started with a terrible defeat that in the end victory was ours!

I've seen many an aircraft carrier and they are indeed impressive warships with tremendous striking power for sheer pyschological impact they don't hold a candle to the sight of a battleship like the Mighty Mo with those huge guns.

replies.context: They didn’t receive the half of what they deserved for their many atrocities during WW2.

Japan went to war against the US and Britain, after Churchill and FDR cut off all supplies of oil to Japan.  Before the oil embargo, Japan considered Stalin's "evil communist empire" as the main potential enemy.  Stalin was worried that Japan might join the European Axis Powers in the war against the USSR.   The Japanese Army favored this course of action, especially since there were some oilfields on Northern Sakhalin Island, which was controlled by the USSR.
For this reason, Stalin did his best to promote a war between the USA and Japan.  In the end, Japan chose to go after the oilfields in Dutch Indonesia, which meant war with the USA and Britain.  Japanese Navy bombers sank HMS Prince of Wales and HMS Repulse on Dec 10 1941, near Singapore.  Note that Japan was allied with the British Empire during WW-1, and took over the German colony in China (Tsingtau), and the German Pacific Islands. 
Some interesting books:
"The New Dealer's War", by Thomas Fleming
"Stalin's War", by Sean McMeeken
"Stalin's Secret Agents", by Evans and Romerstein
"Infamy", by John Toland

context: Japan only surrendered because of the atomic bombs dropped. But for what I have seen.  In the battlefield.  They we're actually winning.

replies.context: you really need to learn history.
So what was the need for the atomic bombs?? If America was winning why the bombs??

Shortest path to victory. If you had read your history, you would have discovered that the US was planning Operation Downfall -the land invasion of the Japanese islands, which was planned for November, 1945. Had the atom bombs not been used, we would have gone forward with that invasion. Operation Downfall would have made D-Day look like a beach picnic. The War Department was estimating US casualties in the millions; as the Japanese had demonstrated that they would not surrender..
You sir are very correct.
The atomic bombs we're dropped in civilian crowded cities.  Not military targets.

Um, wrong. Hiroshima had a rather large munitions plant, a massive army base, as well as being the HQ of the 2nd (Japanese) Army. Nagasaki wasn't originally selected as a target, as Maj. Sweeney and his B29, Bocscar, intended to Bomb Kokura, but there was too much cloud cover that morning. Nagasaki was a target of opportunity..
During all out war, there are no civilians.  As a civilian working in an aerospace defense plant I always considered myself a target.
Sounds like something my grandfather once said; "In war, boy, there are only two kinds of people, the winners, and the dead." He saw action in the Ardennes Forest and the Ruhr, 1944/45

Um, no they weren't. They were beaten by early 1945. When the B29s Operation Meetinghouse (the firebombing campaign) in the spring, it wasn't long until 2/3 of Japan was obliterated and that was with napalm. The 2 atom bombs were just icing on that cake -probably meant to scare the Russians more than force the defeat of Japan...
The Russians also declared war on Japan immediately after the bombs, rolling over them in China. Japan feared occupation by Russia much more than by the US. Stalin would have literally gutted them.

By 1945, we knew we were going to be in a Cold War with Russia. Stalin was in no position to occupy Japan, let alone attack them. His forces in the East were stretched super thin and he was having issues with the Chinese/Mongolian border -as China and Russia fought several border wars before, during, and after WWII. We dropped the atom bombs (i think) to make Stalin think twice about messing with us as Japan was going to be our occupation sphere..

Partly correct, but you are wrong about Stalin and Japan, he was rolling over them in Manchuria after the forces were release from their struggle with Germany. Japan surrendered not from the bombs alone, they feared Stalin. That was the original subject, you strayed. Japanese history is where I encountered that perspective.
Correct. But Stalin never had designs on Japan, as I stated, we and the Japanese thought he did.
That is an assumption that liberals in the 60's convinced themselves to be fact. Truman didn't give a seconds thought to Russia. This was all about avoiding the invasion of Japan.

I never said it was fact, it's my assertion -based on documents that were found after the US left Japan in 1951. MacArthur (head of the US occupying forces) had serious thoughts about Russia being so close and had expressed his concerns about Soviet interference. The atomic bombs, therefore, in my opinion, served two purposes..
MacArthur wasn't in the loop concerning the Manhattan Project. I'm sure he had his post war concerns but that was to come after the bombs were used.
No, he wasn't aware of the particulars of the Manhattan Project, until sometime in late July -but he did know something very big was in the works..
Truman. who authorized the attack, didn't know about it the day FDR died. That is how tight a lid they kept on this.
True, as Truman wasn't a very popular fellow around the WH in those days; i suspect FDR's cabinet kept him out of a lot of things..
They didn't know who he was. Fun fact. FDR met with Truman a total of two times in his fourth term.

Truman didn't care about the Russians, not yet anyway -but MacArthur did, and the two didn't like one another very much. MacArthur was thinking ahead to the Cold War, Truman was still stuck in WWII mode..
This is accurate, according to a conglomeration of written records.

Actually, Japan was defeated when their Navy and merchant marine were almost totally destroyed, which was achieved by early 1945.  At that point, they had no means to continue the war.  An invasion, of the use of atomic weapons was not necessary to get them to the "peace table".
We should have used the atomic weapons against Stalin's "evil communist empire" the USSR, if necessary, to get the Red Army and NKVD out of Eastern Europe (including the Baltic States and Ukraine).  Stalin didn't get his first atomic weapon until 1945, even with the help of his agents in the FDR administration, at within the Manhattan Project.  Stalin gave Kim Il-sung the "go ahead" to invade "South" Korea in 1950.
Some interesting books:
"Stalin's War", by Sean McMeeken
"Stalin's Secret Agents", by Evans and Romerstein
"Churchill's Third World War", by Jonathan Walker

But don't forget that Japan itself, was still a threat, hence Operation Downfall -which was set to go In November. It was either drop the bombs and hope Japan surrenders, or invade and cost millions of American lives -not to mention wiping out the Japanese people.

My recommendation would be not to say something like to any WWII Veterans still
around. You'll get a lesson in history if you do if they don't knock your head off..
And to most of them, their memories are still fresh when it comes to that time; be prepared for a real lesson in history should you encounter one..
The Japanese public figured out the war wasn't going their way when all of Japans "great victories" were getting closer and closer to home.
The smart ones always knew better; you can't keep millions of soldiers, sailors, and airmen from writing letters back home...
Between censorship and a sunken merchant fleet you'd be surprised. The infamous Letter's from Iwo Jima never left the island.

Like us, the Japanese ground-pounder often wrote in code. More information made it back to the home islands than most people realize. My own grandfather's letters from Germany were written in code, every 10th, 11th, and 12th letter, across the 1st, 2nd, 3rd and so-on sentence spelled out a German town or village he went through. My grandmother showed me his letters and his system

No. They were getting ready to surrender anyways after being fire bombed into nothing. But the. you can't give out loans to rebuild a country that hasn't been destroyed. There was no logical or strategic reason for kamikaze attacking pearl harbor other than to bring the US into war. Which doesn't make sense bc we wasn't going back to war with everything going on. Why fly halfway around the world attack a few ships and then do nothing to capitalize afterwards? But just sit back and wait for retaliation that wouldn't of come without pearl harbor? For a country that specialized in warfare for a thousand years, makes zero sense. Unless someone wanted Japan to be the way it is now.

There were no Kamikaze involved in the Pearl Harbor attack, on Dec 7, 1941.  Japan went to war against the US and Britain, after Churchill and FDR established the oil embargo against Japan, in 1941.  They attacked to US fleet at Pearl Harbor, and the British fleet at Singapore, prior to capturing the oilfields in the Dutch Indonesia.

context: The Japanese culture seemed so alien to Westerners at that time. They would never surrender, very few prisoners were taken. They would volunteer for kamikaze missions and their treatment of POW's was horrendous. That's why the atomic bombs were deemed necessary.

replies.context: They were deemed necessary bc they had to be used on a live city to show what they were capable of to the world. Japan was bombed into oblivion before the atomic bombs were ever dropped. Paper and wood didn't hold up well. There was zero other reason for using those bombs. We produced enough tanks and planes and arms to make California 60 billion dollars. All those planes in that photo? Why bring another opponent into war with you when your already invading several countries? And the US had already said they wasn't returning to war just prior to pearl harbor. But being attacked, nobody asked any questions.

Not quite. Had the atom bombs not been used, we would have had to invade the Japanese home islands. If we thought resistance was ferocious on Okinowa, just think what going house-to-house in Tokyo would have been like. It was either the atom bombs or Operation Downfall -where the War Department was predicting 7-figure US casualties. The Japanese civilian populace would have been obliterated for sure. A tough decision, but the right one.

The Japanese Navy and merchant marine was destroyed by early 1945.  At that point, Japan did not have the imports of food, oil, coal, and steel to enable them to continue the war.  They would have been forced to the "peace table", without an invasion, or without the use of atomic weapons.
Our atomic weapons would have been more useful in forcing Stalin's Red Army and NKVD out of Eastern Europe (including Poland, the Baltic States, and Ukraine).  The communist dictator didn't get his first atomic weapon until 1949.  He launched the Korean War in 1950.

Japan may not have been able to field a modern, mechanized fighting force, but the civilian population was being whipped up into a frenzy -how Americans were going to eat their children and so-on. War Department estimates for the invasion put the Japanese civilian casualties at 90%+. Operation Downfall was in its final preparations. It was going to happen, as ships and men were being transferred out of Europe and pre-positioned in Australia, Hawaii, anywhere they could put them. The Japanese were not concerned about "going to the peace table" in the least -they were beaten by early 1945, yet they still unleashed the Kamikaze on our ships -those are not the actions of a nation that is ready or willing to negotiate for peace..

Japan was putting out "peace feelers" via Sweden and the USSR, before the dictator Stalin launched his invasion of Manchuria and Korea.  The Battle of Okinawa (which was part of the Japanese homeland) took place in April of 1945, which resulted in the sinking of the last two major warships of the Japanese Navy, and the destruction of about 1500 Japanese Army and Navy aircraft.
With all imports of food, oil, coal, and steel cut off, Japan had no means to continue the war, whether or not we invaded, or used atomic weapons.  Eisenhower and MacArthur agreed with this blockade strategy.  
The Japanese government was looking for a way out of the war, as long as Stalin's communist "barbarians" were kept out of Japan.  Stalin did manage to grab the Kuril Islands and South Sakhalin Island.  Anyway, our atomic weapons would have been more useful against Stalin's communist empire, the USSR.
Some interesting books:
"The New Dealer's War", by Thomas Fleming
"Stalin's War", by Sean McMeeken
"Stalin's Secret Agents", by Evans and Romerstein
"Churchill's Third World War", by Jonathan Walker

replies.context:
Just a head up, they are not called canons.  They are technically called naval riffles, but at the very least, call them guns.  The guns on the Missouri are Mark 7 16"/50cal, arguably the most powerful naval riffle ever mounted on a battleship.
The HE (high explosive) shells stood around 5ft tall and weighed 1900lbs, while the super heavy AP (armor piercing) shells stood right 6ft tall and weighed 2700lbs.  Truly awesome weapons.

My dad served in the Navy in Hawaii during WW II.  He, my mother, and several members of our family have been among the 8 million visitors who have trodden her decks since she arrived in Pearl Harbor.  (Though not a member of her crew, for dad it wasn't the first time he'd been aboard)  My wife and I haven't been there yet, but we're making plans.

Her sisters USS Iowa and USS New Jersey are also preserved as museum ships - Iowa in Los Angeles and New Jersey in Camden.  Frankly, attracting funding and visitors has been a problem for those two ships.  As a naval / maritime enthusiast, I think USS Missouri is better off in Pearl Harbor than on the mainland.

context: It is fitting that we remember those who gave their lives and those who served to protect the country in World War Two. Approximately 100,000 American servicemen's  lives were lost each year during the war. That is roughly the same number of Americans we are losing each year to drug overdoses from the drugs coming across our open southern border. My family had three members who were veterans of World War Two. I can't help but wonder what they would think of the invasion and casualties we are suffering today because we have surrendered to an unarmed invasion and international criminals whom our president has given an open invitation to invade.

Those surrender pictures tell a story in themselves.  A very formal event with the Japaneses dressed in formal attire while MacArthur, and every officer was dressed in class C uniforms without even ties, jackets or pressed  clothing.   Also unknown to most WWII buffs the surrender was not unconditional as stated, but with special conditions making the Emperor untouchable. and even protected.  Unlike Germany there were very few war crime trials even though the atrocities  committed by the Japanese were as bad and even worse !

replies.context: Most WW2 buffs do know that where I live.

I’m a WWII buff and have travelled to many sites in Europe and the Pacific. There were a significant number of Japanese war crime trials but they just were not as hyped as Nuremburg. I have dove on the sunken Japanese wrecks at Truk Lagoon that were sunk during air raids in February 1944. Truk is a place few know about, since the U.S. military by passed it vs. invading. All of the U.S. pilots who were shot down during the attacks on Truk were tortured and murdered by the Japanese. Eventually, numerous Japanese were tried for that war crime and executed, but few people know this occurred.

Both of my parents served in WW2.  My Father was on a mine sweeper and my Mother was a nurse on Guam.   The only thing my Dad would say was He and his crew mates had to live with the fact that they could be blown to tiny pieces at any second.  My mother was a nurse, and Guam was the first stop on the way home for soldiers injured in battle.  As you could imagine lots of the men and women had horrible injuries.  So, she never spoke about it, ever.   Like many of the great warriors from that time they have passed on, so I want to thank them and all who served in WW2.

context: Next to the USS Arizona at Pearl Harbor is a fitting place for the USS Missouri to be moored. The Arizona, killed by sneak attack on the first day of the war, still bleeding oil from her wounds after all these years, laying on the bottom with so many of her crew forever entombed; and next to her the Missouri, symbol of America's righteous retribution and victory on whose deck the Arizona's killers were forced to surrender.
